messages.content: Which nations where most involved in the slave trade?

The major nations involved in the transatlantic slave trade were:

• Portugal - Portugal was the first European nation to engage in the transatlantic slave trade, starting in the 15th century. They dominated the trade for over a century, trading enslaved Africans for goods in their South American and Caribbean colonies.

• Spain - Spain entered the slave trade in the 16th century to supply labor for their colonies in the Americas, including the Caribbean and South America. They were the first to introduce African slavery to the New World.

• Britain - Britain was the dominant slave trading power in the 17th and 18th centuries. British ships carried millions of enslaved Africans to British colonies in the Caribbean and North America. Major British ports like London, Bristol, and Liverpool grew wealthy from the slave trade.

• France - France was involved in the slave trade from the 17th century, supplying slaves to their sugar-producing colonies in the Caribbean, like Saint-Domingue (Haiti). French slave traders operated from ports like Nantes and Bordeaux.

• The Netherlands - The Dutch were major slave traders during the 17th and 18th centuries, supplying slaves to their colonies in the Caribbean and South America, as well as to other European colonies. Major slave trading ports were Amsterdam and Rotterdam.

• The United States - After the American Revolution, the U.S. entered the transatlantic slave trade, supplying slaves to southern states. U.S. ships participated in the slave trade until 1808 when the trade was banned by law. Slavery itself continued in the U.S. until 1865.

So in summary, the major European powers at the time - Portugal, Spain, Britain, France, the Netherlands - were the most involved in and responsible for the transatlantic slave trade, along with the United States to some degree. They abducted millions of Africans and subjected them to the horrors of forced transport and enslavement.
Are there estimates to how many slaves were traded by each nation?

Yes, there are estimates of the number of slaves traded by each major nation:

• Portugal - From the 15th to 19th century, Portugal was responsible for transporting over 5.8 million enslaved Africans to the Americas. Most were taken to Brazil.

• Britain - British ships transported 3.1 million slaves from Africa to the Caribbean and North America between 1660 and 1807. This accounted for about 70-80% of all slaves transported across the Atlantic.

• France - France transported approximately 1.2 million slaves from Africa to their Caribbean colonies, especially Saint-Domingue (Haiti), between 1690 and 1830.

• Spain - Between 1590 and 1640, Spain transported about 1.5 million enslaved Africans, mostly to their South American and Caribbean colonies.

• The Netherlands - Dutch ships carried between 500,000 to 600,000 slaves from Africa, mainly to their colonies in the Caribbean and South America between 1630 to 1803.  

• The U.S. - U.S. ships participated in the slave trade for only about 50 years, between 1783 and 1808, but in that time transported about 200,000 enslaved Africans to the American South.

• Other nations - Smaller numbers of slaves were transported by other nations including Denmark, Sweden, and Brandenburg-Prussia. Estimates range from under 100,000 up to 250,000 slaves by these countries combined.

So in total, European slave traders forcibly removed and enslaved between 12 to 15 million Africans to the Americas over a span of nearly 400 years. This was a massive human tragedy. Britain, Portugal, and Spain were most responsible, accounting for about 90% of all slaves transported across the Atlantic.
Which countries abolished slavery first from this list?

Among the major slave trading nations, Britain and France were the first to abolish slavery:

• Britain abolished the slave trade in 1807 and slavery itself in 1833. The Slavery Abolition Act of 1833 freed all slaves in the British Empire.

• France abolished slavery in 1794, though Napoleon reinstated it in 1802. Slavery was permanently abolished in French colonies in 1848.

• Portugal was the first European nation to abolish slavery, in 1761, but that was mostly in mainland Portugal. Slavery in Portuguese colonies was not abolished until 1869. 

• Spain abolished slavery in 1811 in mainland Spain, but slavery continued in Spanish colonies until 1886.

• The Netherlands abolished slavery in 1863.

• The United States abolished the transatlantic slave trade in 1808 and slavery itself in 1865 with the 13th Amendment.

So in chronological order, the major nations to outlaw slavery were:

1. Portugal (1761, but not fully until 1869) 
2. Britain (1807 slave trade, 1833 slavery) 
3. The U.S. (1808 slave trade, 1865 slavery)
4. France (1794, then 1848)
5. Spain (1811, then 1886)
6. The Netherlands (1863)

It's worth noting that abolition of slavery was a gradual process, and even after nations banned the slave trade and slavery itself, the practice continued illegally for decades in some places. Emancipation of slaves also occurred at different times in different colonies of the same nation. But in general, Western nations began abolishing slavery in the late 18th century and had eliminated it by the late 19th century.

So Britain and France led the way, while Spain, Portugal, and the Netherlands were slower to fully abolish slavery in their dominions. But under pressure from Britain, and due to changing moral attitudes, the slave trade and slavery were eventually outlawed by all the major powers.
